title: Hub Arkush: Bears' rebuilding a bit ahead of schedule right now
text:
Hub Arkush: Bears' rebuilding a bit ahead of schedule right now Published: Sunday, Oct. 11, 2015 6:50 p.m. CDT • Updated: Sunday, Oct. 11, 2015 6:53 p.m. CDT Caption (Charlie Riedel) Bears quarterback Jay Cutler rolls out of the pocket during the second half Sunday against the Kansas City Chiefs in Kansas City, Mo. 
It was Stephen Stills who wrote and Buffalo Springfield that sang, “There’s something happening here, what it is aint exactly clear.” 
It was December of 1966 and while Stills clearly had a very different subject matter in mind, the lyrics that became an anthem from Buffalo Springfield for the peace movement of the ‘60s absolutely apply to the 2015 Bears through five weeks of the 2015 season. 
In a game the Bears shouldn’t have won and seemingly couldn’t win, they took a huge step forward as a team and as an organization with their improbable 18-17 win Sunday over Kansas City. 
The Chiefs had a lot more talent on the field than the Bears did, and who knows what happens if Jamaal Charles doesn’t go down or if Kansas City quarterback Alex Smith hadn’t done his best Jonathan Quinn imitation for the better part of the game? 
But the bottom line is the Bears had the biggest hearts on the field, were the better-coached team and worked with what they had, executing much better than the Chiefs almost to the end. 
With the Bears playing without Alshon Jeffery, Eddie Royal, Jermon Bushrod, Will Montgomery and Antrel Rolle, the Charles injury is irrelevant. 
The Chiefs should have hammered the Bears, with or without him. 
Sure, Smith stunk, but I’ve broadcast enough of Smith’s games, including the Chiefs 45-44 loss to the Colts in a 2013 AFC wild-card game, to know Smith is capable of playing like an All-Pro. 
Vic Fangio and his guys had a ton to do with Smith’s woeful performance. 
After looking like they were going to be blown out with the second half coming to an end, the Bears stopped Jeremy Maclin three yards short of a first down at their 16 and forced a field goal to make it a 17-3 game. 
Next, the Chiefs took the second-half kickoff 71 yards on 13 plays only to have McPhee block a 27-yard Cairo Santos field-goal attempt, and the Bears defense took over from there. 
Fangio started dialing up pressures that included Houston and Young, and each garnered their first QB sacks of the season. 
Porter had another excellent game in coverage, primarily on Jeremy Maclin, who was held to 85 yards on eight catches after back-to-back monster games with double-digit catches and more than 140 yards in each. The Bears' kiddie corps at safety of Adrian Moss and Harold Jones-Quartey again avoided the spotlight and made enough plays to get another win. 
Fangio is clearly an excellent coach who is making this defense far bigger and better than the sum of its parts. 
At the end of the day, however, the main plotline in the Bears’ heroic victory over the Chiefs is once again the play of Jay Cutler. 
Sure, Matt Forte’s huge, but he’s an All-Pro giving the team what it expects. 
Martellus Bennett struggled in Kansas City, and while Marquess Wilson, Josh Bellamy and Cameron Meredith all made big plays, none have done enough to convince us they have futures with the team. 
Hroniss Grasu went from awful to impressive in 60 minutes, and Kyle Long was outstanding. 
But for the better part of Sunday, Cutler was an elite quarterback. Who can honestly say they saw that coming? 
Is it thanks to Adam Gase? John Fox? 
It “aint exactly clear” yet but they’re obviously not hurting. 
And here’s one more thought. Eddie Goldman, Grasu, Jeremy Langford, Amos, Patrick Omameh, McPhee, Acho, Jones-Quartey, Porter and other contributors all have one thing in common – none of them were here last year. 
It seems Ryan Pace has something to do with this as well. 
Hear me folks, it’s early. This is still a .500 team on its best day. Not every Sunday will go the way this one did. 
But what’s happening here is that Pace and Fox know they’ve got a rebuild on their hands, and their plan might just be a little bit ahead of schedule right now.
